mn21:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn21:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn21:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṃ ativelaṃ saṃsaṭṭho viharati.
mn21:2.1.eng: Now at that time, Venerable Phagguna of the Top-Knot was spending too long mixing closely with some nuns.
mn21:2.1.comm: This monk appears in three discourses, in none of which he distinguishes himself. At SN 12.12 he persistently attempts to rephrase questions on dependent origination in terms of a self. And at SN 12.32 Venerable Sāriputta gets word that Phagguna had disrobed. According to the commentary, he was called Phagguna “of the Top-Knot” because of the style he wore his hair as a layperson. The name stuck, presumably to distinguish him from the Phagguna of AN 6.56 (and probably SN 35.83) who died in robes as a non-returner after hearing a Dhamma talk.

mn21:2.2.pli: Evaṃ saṃsaṭṭho āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṃ viharati—

mn21:2.3.pli: sace koci bhikkhu āyasmato moḷiyaphaggunassa sammukhā tāsaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, tenāyasmā moḷiyaphagguno kupito anattamano adhikaraṇampi karoti.
mn21:2.3.eng: if any mendicant criticized those nuns in his presence, Phagguna of the Top-Knot got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
mn21:2.3.comm: A “disciplinary proceeding” (adhikaraṇa) is a legal case in Vinaya. A standard set of four is listed at MN 104:12.3. The kind of case is not specified in the text, but the commentary says they accused other mendicants of various offences and got Vinaya experts to litigate them, making it a “disciplinary issue arising from accusations” (anuvādādhikaraṇa, Kd 14:14.2.7).

mn21:2.4.pli: Sace pana koci bhikkhu tāsaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ sammukhā āyasmato moḷiyaphaggunassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, tena tā bhikkhuniyo kupitā anattamanā adhikaraṇampi karonti.
mn21:2.4.eng: And if any mendicant criticized Phagguna of the Top-Knot in their presence, those nuns got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.

mn21:2.5.pli: Evaṃ saṃsaṭṭho āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṃ viharati.
mn21:2.5.eng: That’s how close Phagguna of the Top-Knot was with those nuns.

mn21:3.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn21:3.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was going on.

mn21:3.2.pli: “āyasmā, bhante, moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṃ ativelaṃ saṃsaṭṭho viharati.

mn21:3.3.pli: Evaṃ saṃsaṭṭho, bhante, āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṃ viharati—

mn21:3.4.pli: sace koci bhikkhu āyasmato moḷiyaphaggunassa sammukhā tāsaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, tenāyasmā moḷiyaphagguno kupito anattamano adhikaraṇampi karoti.

mn21:3.5.pli: Sace pana koci bhikkhu tāsaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ sammukhā āyasmato moḷiyaphaggunassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, tena tā bhikkhuniyo kupitā anattamanā adhikaraṇampi karonti.

mn21:3.6.pli: Evaṃ saṃsaṭṭho, bhante, āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṃ viharatī”ti.

mn21:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
mn21:4.1.eng: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,

mn21:4.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena moḷiyaphaggunaṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantehi:
mn21:4.2.eng: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Phagguna of the Top-Knot that

mn21:4.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā yenāyasmā moḷiyaphagguno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ moḷiyaphaggunaṃ etadavoca:
mn21:4.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Phagguna of the Top-Knot and said to him,

mn21:4.6.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno tassa bhikkhuno paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ moḷiyaphaggunaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
mn21:4.6.eng: “Yes, reverend,” Phagguna replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

mn21:5.1.pli: “Saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, phagguna, bhikkhunīhi saddhiṃ ativelaṃ saṃsaṭṭho viharasi?
mn21:5.1.eng: “Is it really true, Phagguna, that you’ve been spending too long mixing closely with some nuns?

mn21:5.2.pli: Evaṃ saṃsaṭṭho kira tvaṃ, phagguna, bhikkhunīhi saddhiṃ viharasi—

mn21:5.3.pli: sace koci bhikkhu tuyhaṃ sammukhā tāsaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, tena tvaṃ kupito anattamano adhikaraṇampi karosi.
mn21:5.3.eng: if any mendicant criticizes those nuns in your presence, you get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings?

mn21:5.4.pli: Sace pana koci bhikkhu tāsaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ sammukhā tuyhaṃ avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, tena tā bhikkhuniyo kupitā anattamanā adhikaraṇampi karonti.
mn21:5.4.eng: And if any mendicant criticizes you in those nuns’ presence, they get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings?

mn21:5.5.pli: Evaṃ saṃsaṭṭho kira tvaṃ, phagguna, bhikkhunīhi saddhiṃ viharasī”ti?
mn21:5.5.eng: Is that how close you’ve become with those nuns?”

mn21:5.7.pli: “Nanu tvaṃ, phagguna, kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito”ti?
mn21:5.7.eng: “Phagguna, are you not a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness?”

mn21:6.1.pli: “Na kho te etaṃ, phagguna, patirūpaṃ kulaputtassa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitassa, yaṃ tvaṃ bhikkhunīhi saddhiṃ ativelaṃ saṃsaṭṭho vihareyyāsi.
mn21:6.1.eng: “As such, it’s not appropriate for you to mix so closely with those nuns.

mn21:6.2.pli: Tasmātiha, phagguna, tava cepi koci sammukhā tāsaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyya, tatrāpi tvaṃ, phagguna, ye gehasitā chandā ye gehasitā vitakkā te pajaheyyāsi.
mn21:6.2.eng: So if anyone criticizes those nuns in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.

mn21:6.3.eng: If that happens, you should train like this:

mn21:6.4.pli: ‘na ceva me cittaṃ vipariṇataṃ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṃ vācaṃ nicchāressāmi, hitānukampī ca viharissāmi mettacitto, na dosantaro’ti.
mn21:6.4.eng: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’

mn21:6.6.pli: Tasmātiha, phagguna, tava cepi koci sammukhā tāsaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ pāṇinā pahāraṃ dadeyya, leḍḍunā pahāraṃ dadeyya, daṇḍena pahāraṃ dadeyya, satthena pahāraṃ dadeyya. Tatrāpi tvaṃ, phagguna, ye gehasitā chandā ye gehasitā vitakkā te pajaheyyāsi.
mn21:6.6.eng: So even if someone strikes those nuns with fists, stones, rods, and swords in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.
mn21:6.6.comm: This does not mean, of course, that one should not defend people against violence (see eg. DN 16:1.4.15), but that even in such circumstances one should not give way to anger.

mn21:6.7.eng: If that happens, you should train like this:

mn21:6.8.pli: ‘na ceva me cittaṃ vipariṇataṃ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṃ vācaṃ nicchāressāmi, hitānukampī ca viharissāmi mettacitto, na dosantaro’ti.
mn21:6.8.eng: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’

mn21:6.10.pli: Tasmātiha, phagguna, tava cepi koci sammukhā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyya, tatrāpi tvaṃ, phagguna, ye gehasitā chandā ye gehasitā vitakkā te pajaheyyāsi.
mn21:6.10.eng: So if anyone criticizes you in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.
mn21:6.10.comm: The grammar here is a little tricky. The genitive plays two roles in these passages: specifying the context (tava sammukhā, “in your presence”), and as the object of criticism or blows (pahāraṁ dadeyya “if they strike” operates above on “those nuns” (tāsaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ) and below on “you” (tava)). Here we would expect both senses to be used, but the text only has tava once. I assume that either one instance of tava has been lost or it is meant to be distributed.

mn21:6.11.pli: Tatrāpi te, phagguna, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ ‘na ceva me cittaṃ vipariṇataṃ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṃ vācaṃ nicchāressāmi, hitānukampī ca viharissāmi mettacitto, na dosantaro’ti.
mn21:6.11.eng: If that happens, you should train like this: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’

mn21:6.13.pli: Tasmātiha, phagguna, tava cepi koci pāṇinā pahāraṃ dadeyya, leḍḍunā pahāraṃ dadeyya, daṇḍena pahāraṃ dadeyya, satthena pahāraṃ dadeyya, tatrāpi tvaṃ, phagguna, ye gehasitā chandā ye gehasitā vitakkā te pajaheyyāsi.
mn21:6.13.eng: So Phagguna, even if someone strikes you with fists, stones, rods, and swords, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.
mn21:6.13.comm: Here sammukhā is omitted, as it is unnecessary to specify being hit in your own presence.

mn21:6.14.pli: Tatrāpi te, phagguna, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ ‘na ceva me cittaṃ vipariṇataṃ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṃ vācaṃ nicchāressāmi, hitānukampī ca viharissāmi mettacitto, na dosantaro’ti.
mn21:6.14.eng: If that happens, you should train like this: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’

mn21:7.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

mn21:7.2.pli: “ārādhayiṃsu vata me, bhikkhave, bhikkhū ekaṃ samayaṃ cittaṃ.
mn21:7.2.eng: “Mendicants, I used to be satisfied with the mendicants.

mn21:7.4.eng: ‘I eat my food in one sitting per day.
mn21:7.4.comm: Eating once a day is also encouraged at MN 65, while MN 70 encourages not eating at night. In both cases, monks objected when asked to follow this practice. Thus all three instances depict the growing influence of recalcitrant monks in the Sangha, culminating in the Buddha laying down a formal Vinaya rule against eating at the wrong time (Bu Pc 37). Per the allowance at MN 65:4.1, the mendicants are not required to eat in one sitting, which remained as an optional ascetic practice.

mn21:7.5.pli: Ekāsanabhojanaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, bhuñjamāno appābādhatañca sañjānāmi appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañca.
mn21:7.5.eng: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

mn21:7.6.eng: You too should eat your food in one sitting per day.

mn21:7.7.pli: Ekāsanabhojanaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tumhepi bhuñjamānā appābādhatañca sañjānissatha appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañcāti.
mn21:7.7.eng: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’

mn21:7.8.pli: Na me, bhikkhave, tesu bhikkhūsu anusāsanī karaṇīyā ahosi;
mn21:7.8.eng: I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants;

mn21:7.9.pli: satuppādakaraṇīyameva me, bhikkhave, tesu bhikkhūsu ahosi.
mn21:7.9.eng: I just had to prompt their mindfulness.
mn21:7.9.comm: This is referring to the early years of the dispensation, before the formal Vinaya code was laid down. The Buddha was reluctant to create a legal code and did so only when it became necessary (Bu Pj 1:3.4.6). He preferred to lead without judgment and punishment, but by reason, positive encouragement, and inspiring with his own example.

mn21:7.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, subhūmiyaṃ catumahāpathe ājaññaratho yutto assa ṭhito odhastapatodo.
mn21:7.10.eng: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.
mn21:7.10.comm: This simile is also at MN 119:31.2, SN 35.239:2.10, and AN 5.28:10.2.

mn21:7.11.pli: Tamenaṃ dakkho yoggācariyo assadammasārathi abhiruhitvā, vāmena hatthena rasmiyo gahetvā, dakkhiṇena hatthena patodaṃ gahetvā, yenicchakaṃ yadicchakaṃ sāreyyapi paccāsāreyyapi.
mn21:7.11.eng: A deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.

mn21:7.12.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, na me tesu bhikkhūsu anusāsanī karaṇīyā ahosi,
mn21:7.12.eng: In the same way, I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants;

mn21:7.13.pli: satuppādakaraṇīyameva me, bhikkhave, tesu bhikkhūsu ahosi.
mn21:7.13.eng: I just had to prompt their mindfulness.

mn21:7.14.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, tumhepi akusalaṃ pajahatha, kusalesu dhammesu āyogaṃ karotha.
mn21:7.14.eng: So, mendicants, you too should give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities.

mn21:7.15.pli: Evañhi tumhepi imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjissatha.
mn21:7.15.eng: In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.

mn21:8.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre mahantaṃ sālavanaṃ.
mn21:8.1.eng: Suppose that not far from a town or village there was a large grove of sal trees

mn21:8.2.eng: that was choked with castor-oil weeds.

mn21:8.3.pli: Tassa kocideva puriso uppajjeyya atthakāmo hitakāmo yogakkhemakāmo.
mn21:8.3.eng: Then along comes a person who wants to help protect and nurture that grove.

mn21:8.4.pli: So yā tā sālalaṭṭhiyo kuṭilā ojāpaharaṇiyo tā chetvā bahiddhā nīhareyya, antovanaṃ suvisodhitaṃ visodheyya.
mn21:8.4.eng: They’d cut down the crooked sal saplings that were robbing the sap, and throw them out. They’d clean up the interior of the grove,

mn21:8.5.pli: Yā pana tā sālalaṭṭhiyo ujukā sujātā tā sammā parihareyya.
mn21:8.5.eng: and properly care for the straight, well-formed sal saplings.

mn21:8.6.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, sālavanaṃ aparena samayena vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyya.
mn21:8.6.eng: In this way, in due course, that sal grove would grow, increase, and mature.

mn21:8.7.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, tumhepi akusalaṃ pajahatha, kusalesu dhammesu āyogaṃ karotha.
mn21:8.7.eng: In the same way, mendicants, you too should give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities.

mn21:8.8.pli: Evañhi tumhepi imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjissatha.
mn21:8.8.eng: In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.

mn21:9.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, imissāyeva sāvatthiyā vedehikā nāma gahapatānī ahosi.
mn21:9.1.eng: Once upon a time, mendicants, right here in Sāvatthī there was a housewife named Vedehikā.
mn21:9.1.comm: The lady Vedehikā is known only here. According to the commentary, her name means either “daughter of the lady from Videha”, or (implausibly) “wise one”. However, the much earlier Arthaśāstra treats vaidehika either as a “merchant” (2.21.7) or as a caste name (3.7.32). This story paints a rare portrait of domestic life.

mn21:9.2.pli: Vedehikāya, bhikkhave, gahapatāniyā evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

mn21:9.3.pli: ‘soratā vedehikā gahapatānī, nivātā vedehikā gahapatānī, upasantā vedehikā gahapatānī’ti.
mn21:9.3.eng: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is gentle, even-tempered, and calm.’
mn21:9.3.comm: The same set of three in a similar context occur at AN 6.60.

mn21:9.4.pli: Vedehikāya kho pana, bhikkhave, gahapatāniyā kāḷī nāma dāsī ahosi dakkhā analasā susaṃvihitakammantā.
mn21:9.4.eng: Now, Vedehikā had a bonded maid named Kāḷī who was deft, tireless, and well-organized in her work.
mn21:9.4.comm: According to ancient Indian law (Arthaśāstra 3.13), slaves may be born such, be captured in war, or a person in a time of trouble may bind themselves in service for a fee. Non-Aryans (mleccha) may indenture their children, but this is forbidden for Aryans. Such bondservants were protected against cruelty, sexual abuse, and unfair work. After earning back the fee of their indenture they were freed, retaining their original inheritance and status. | The maid’s name means “black” (compare the Kāḷī at Thag 2.16:1.1 who “looks like a crow”). This is a persistent pattern in early Pali. The only other named slaves are Disā (“foe”, DN 3:1.16.1), her son Kaṇha (“black”, DN 3:1.16.1), and Kāka (“crow”, Kd 8:1.26.6). These people were evidently non-Aryans descended from the native peoples of India, perhaps Tamils or other tribal groups.

mn21:9.5.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷiyā dāsiyā etadahosi:

mn21:9.6.pli: ‘mayhaṃ kho ayyāya evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
mn21:9.6.eng: ‘My mistress has a good reputation as being

mn21:9.7.pli: “soratā vedehikā gahapatānī, nivātā vedehikā gahapatānī, upasantā vedehikā gahapatānī”ti.

mn21:9.8.pli: Kiṃ nu kho me ayyā santaṃyeva nu kho ajjhattaṃ kopaṃ na pātukaroti udāhu asantaṃ
mn21:9.8.eng: But does she actually have anger in her and just not show it? Or does she have no anger?

mn21:9.9.pli: udāhu mayhamevete kammantā susaṃvihitā yena me ayyā santaṃyeva ajjhattaṃ kopaṃ na pātukaroti, no asantaṃ?
mn21:9.9.eng: Or is it just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside?

mn21:9.10.eng: Why don’t I test my mistress?’
mn21:9.10.comm: To “test” (or “inquire”) is vīmaṁsā, which features as the fourth of the bases of psychic power.

mn21:9.11.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷī dāsī divā uṭṭhāsi.
mn21:9.11.eng: So Kāḷī got up during the day.

mn21:9.12.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vedehikā gahapatānī kāḷiṃ dāsiṃ etadavoca:

mn21:9.13.comm: He je is an idiomatic and disrespectful form of address, offering a glimpse of colloquial speech in the formal Pali of scripture. He is an exclamation for calling attention, like “hey” but cruder. Je is a derogatory term for women, used here and by the Vajjīs to Ambapālī at DN 16:2.16.3.

mn21:9.14.comm: She uses the respectful address ayye (“ma’am”).

mn21:9.15.eng: ‘You’re getting up in the day—what’s up with you, wench?’

mn21:9.17.pli: ‘No vata re kiñci, pāpi dāsi, divā uṭṭhāsī’ti kupitā anattamanā bhākuṭiṃ akāsi.
mn21:9.17.eng: ‘Oh, so nothing’s up, you naughty maid, but you get up in the day!’ Angry and upset, she scowled.

mn21:9.18.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷiyā dāsiyā etadahosi:

mn21:9.19.pli: ‘santaṃyeva kho me ayyā ajjhattaṃ kopaṃ na pātukaroti, no asantaṃ;
mn21:9.19.eng: ‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger.

mn21:9.20.pli: mayhamevete kammantā susaṃvihitā, yena me ayyā santaṃyeva ajjhattaṃ kopaṃ na pātukaroti, no asantaṃ.
mn21:9.20.eng: It’s just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside.

mn21:9.21.eng: Why don’t I test my mistress further?’

mn21:9.22.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷī dāsī divātaraṃyeva uṭṭhāsi.
mn21:9.22.eng: So Kāḷī got up later in the day.

mn21:9.23.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vedehikā gahapatānī kāḷiṃ dāsiṃ etadavoca:

mn21:9.26.eng: ‘You’re getting up later in the day—what’s up with you, wench?’

mn21:9.28.pli: ‘No vata re kiñci, pāpi dāsi, divātaraṃ uṭṭhāsī’ti kupitā anattamanā anattamanavācaṃ nicchāresi.
mn21:9.28.eng: ‘Oh, so nothing’s up, you naughty maid, but you get up later in the day!’ Angry and upset, she blurted out angry words.

mn21:9.29.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷiyā dāsiyā etadahosi:

mn21:9.30.pli: ‘santaṃyeva kho me ayyā ajjhattaṃ kopaṃ na pātukaroti, no asantaṃ.
mn21:9.30.eng: ‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger.

mn21:9.31.pli: Mayhamevete kammantā susaṃvihitā, yena me ayyā santaṃyeva ajjhattaṃ kopaṃ na pātukaroti, no asantaṃ.
mn21:9.31.eng: It’s just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside.

mn21:9.32.eng: Why don’t I test my mistress further?’

mn21:9.33.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷī dāsī divātaraṃyeva uṭṭhāsi.
mn21:9.33.eng: So Kāḷī got up even later in the day.
mn21:9.33.comm: Assuming that the three rounds are meant to be divā, divātaraṁ, divātaraṁyeva (“in the day”, “later in the day”, “even later in the day”), although this is not followed consistently in the text.

mn21:9.34.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vedehikā gahapatānī kāḷiṃ dāsiṃ etadavoca:

mn21:9.37.eng: ‘You’re getting up even later in the day—what’s up with you, wench?’

mn21:9.39.pli: ‘No vata re kiñci, pāpi dāsi, divā uṭṭhāsī’ti kupitā anattamanā aggaḷasūciṃ gahetvā sīse pahāraṃ adāsi, sīsaṃ vobhindi.
mn21:9.39.eng: ‘Oh, so nothing’s up, you naughty maid, but you get up even later in the day!’ Angry and upset, she grabbed a door-pin and hit Kāḷī on the head, cracking it open.
mn21:9.39.comm: Aggaḷasūci is a “pin” (sūci) for fastening the “door” (aggala). It is sometimes translated as “rolling pin”, but that would be Sanskrit vellana (Hindi belan).

mn21:9.40.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷī dāsī bhinnena sīsena lohitena galantena paṭivissakānaṃ ujjhāpesi:
mn21:9.40.eng: Then Kāḷī, with blood pouring from her cracked skull, denounced her mistress to the neighbors,

mn21:9.41.eng: ‘See, ladies, what the gentle one did!

mn21:9.42.pli: passathayye, nivātāya kammaṃ, passathayye, upasantāya kammaṃ.
mn21:9.42.eng: See what the even-tempered one did! See what the calm one did!

mn21:9.43.pli: Kathañhi nāma ekadāsikāya divā uṭṭhāsīti kupitā anattamanā aggaḷasūciṃ gahetvā sīse pahāraṃ dassati, sīsaṃ vobhindissatī’ti.
mn21:9.43.eng: How on earth can she grab a door-pin and hit her only maid on the head, cracking it open, just for getting up late?’
mn21:9.43.comm: Arthaśāstra 3.13.9 says that inflicting punishment (daṇḍapreṣaṇam; cf. Pali daṇḍāpesuṁ at Bi Ss 1:1.38) on a slave is a crime for which a master incurs a fine equivalent to the cost of the slave.

mn21:9.44.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vedehikāya gahapatāniyā aparena samayena evaṃ pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchi:
mn21:9.44.eng: Then after some time the housewife Vedehikā got this bad reputation:

mn21:9.45.pli: ‘caṇḍī vedehikā gahapatānī, anivātā vedehikā gahapatānī, anupasantā vedehikā gahapatānī’ti.
mn21:9.45.eng: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is fierce, ill-tempered, and not calm at all.’
mn21:9.45.comm: No blame is given to Kāḷī for her deliberate provocation.

mn21:10.1.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu tāvadeva soratasorato hoti nivātanivāto hoti upasantūpasanto hoti yāva na amanāpā vacanapathā phusanti.
mn21:10.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant may be the gentlest of the gentle, the most even-tempered of the even-tempered, the calmest of the calm, so long as they don’t encounter any disagreeable criticism.

mn21:10.2.pli: Yato ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ amanāpā vacanapathā phusanti, atha bhikkhu ‘sorato’ti veditabbo, ‘nivāto’ti veditabbo, ‘upasanto’ti veditabbo.
mn21:10.2.eng: But it’s when they encounter disagreeable criticism that you’ll know whether they’re really gentle, even-tempered, and calm.

mn21:10.3.pli: Nāhaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ ‘suvaco’ti vadāmi yo cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārahetu suvaco hoti, sovacassataṃ āpajjati.
mn21:10.3.eng: I don’t say that a mendicant is easy to admonish if they make themselves easy to admonish only for the sake of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

mn21:10.5.pli: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ alabhamāno na suvaco hoti, na sovacassataṃ āpajjati.
mn21:10.5.eng: Because when they don’t get robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, they’re no longer easy to admonish.

mn21:10.6.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammaṃyeva sakkaronto, dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto, dhammaṃ mānento, dhammaṃ pūjento, dhammaṃ apacāyamāno suvaco hoti, sovacassataṃ āpajjati, tamahaṃ ‘suvaco’ti vadāmi.
mn21:10.6.eng: But when a mendicant is easy to admonish purely because they honor, respect, revere, worship, and venerate the teaching, then I say that they’re easy to admonish.

mn21:10.7.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘dhammaṃyeva sakkarontā, dhammaṃ garuṃ karontā, dhammaṃ mānentā, dhammaṃ pūjentā, dhammaṃ apacāyamānā suvacā bhavissāma, sovacassataṃ āpajjissāmā’ti.
mn21:10.7.eng: So, mendicants, you should train yourselves: ‘We will be easy to admonish purely because we honor, respect, revere, worship, and venerate the teaching.’

mn21:11.1.pli: Pañcime, bhikkhave, vacanapathā yehi vo pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ—
mn21:11.1.eng: Mendicants, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you.
mn21:11.1.comm: At AN 5.167 and AN 10.44:7.1 the five positive ways should be established before admonishing anyone.

mn21:11.2.eng: Their speech may be timely or untimely,

mn21:11.6.eng: from a heart of love or from secret hate.

mn21:11.7.pli: Kālena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ akālena vā;
mn21:11.7.eng: When others criticize you, they may do so in any of these ways.

mn21:11.8.pli: bhūtena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ abhūtena vā;

mn21:11.9.pli: saṇhena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ pharusena vā;

mn21:11.10.pli: atthasaṃhitena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ anatthasaṃhitena vā;

mn21:11.11.pli: mettacittā vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ dosantarā vā.

mn21:11.12.eng: If that happens, you should train like this:

mn21:11.13.pli: ‘na ceva no cittaṃ vipariṇataṃ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṃ vācaṃ nicchāressāma, hitānukampī ca viharissāma mettacittā, na dosantarā.
mn21:11.13.eng: ‘Our minds will not degenerate. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.

mn21:11.14.pli: Tañca puggalaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā pharitvā viharissāma, tadārammaṇañca sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cittena vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharissāmā’ti.
mn21:11.14.eng: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that individual. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart full of love to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
mn21:11.14.comm: Up until now, the sutta has concerned itself with good behavior and motivations in everyday life. Now this forms a basis to support meditation.

mn21:12.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso āgaccheyya kudālapiṭakaṃ ādāya.
mn21:12.1.eng: Suppose a person was to come along carrying a spade and basket

mn21:12.3.eng: ‘I shall make this great earth be without earth!’

mn21:12.4.pli: So tatra tatra vikhaṇeyya, tatra tatra vikireyya, tatra tatra oṭṭhubheyya, tatra tatra omutteyya:
mn21:12.4.eng: And they’d dig all over, scatter all over, spit all over, and urinate all over, saying,

mn21:12.7.pli: api nu so puriso imaṃ mahāpathaviṃ apathaviṃ kareyyā”ti?
mn21:12.7.eng: Could that person make this great earth be without earth?”

mn21:12.10.eng: Because this great earth is deep and limitless.

mn21:12.11.eng: It’s not easy to make it be without earth.

mn21:12.12.pli: yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
mn21:12.12.eng: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

mn21:13.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, pañcime vacanapathā yehi vo pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ—
mn21:13.1.eng: “In the same way, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you.

mn21:13.2.eng: Their speech may be timely or untimely,

mn21:13.6.eng: from a heart of love or from secret hate.

mn21:13.7.pli: Kālena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ akālena vā;
mn21:13.7.eng: When others criticize you, they may do so in any of these ways.

mn21:13.8.pli: bhūtena vā bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ abhūtena vā;

mn21:13.9.pli: saṇhena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ pharusena vā;

mn21:13.10.pli: atthasaṃhitena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ anatthasaṃhitena vā;

mn21:13.11.pli: mettacittā vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ dosantarā vā.

mn21:13.12.eng: If that happens, you should train like this:

mn21:13.13.pli: ‘na ceva no cittaṃ vipariṇataṃ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṃ vācaṃ nicchāressāma, hitānukampī ca viharissāma mettacittā na dosantarā.
mn21:13.13.eng: ‘Our minds will not degenerate. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.

mn21:13.14.pli: Tañca puggalaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā pharitvā viharissāma, tadārammaṇañca sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ pathavisamena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharissāmā’ti.
mn21:13.14.eng: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that individual. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart like the earth to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’

mn21:14.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso āgaccheyya lākhaṃ vā haliddiṃ vā nīlaṃ vā mañjiṭṭhaṃ vā ādāya.
mn21:14.1.eng: Suppose a person was to come along with dye such as red lac, turmeric, indigo, or rose madder,

mn21:14.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ imasmiṃ ākāse rūpaṃ likhissāmi, rūpapātubhāvaṃ karissāmī’ti.
mn21:14.3.eng: ‘I shall draw pictures in space, making pictures appear there.’

mn21:14.5.pli: api nu so puriso imasmiṃ ākāse rūpaṃ likheyya, rūpapātubhāvaṃ kareyyā”ti?
mn21:14.5.eng: Could that person draw pictures in space?”

mn21:14.8.eng: Because space has no form or appearance.
mn21:14.8.comm: “No form or appearance” is arūpī anidassano.

mn21:14.9.pli: Tattha na sukaraṃ rūpaṃ likhituṃ, rūpapātubhāvaṃ kātuṃ;
mn21:14.9.eng: It’s not easy to draw pictures there.

mn21:14.10.pli: yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
mn21:14.10.eng: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

mn21:15.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, pañcime vacanapathā yehi vo pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ kālena vā akālena vā …pe…
mn21:15.1.eng: “In the same way, if others criticize you in any of these five ways … you should train like this:

mn21:15.2.pli: tadārammaṇañca sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ ākāsasamena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharissāmā’ti.
mn21:15.2.eng: ‘… We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that person. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart like space to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’

mn21:16.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso āgaccheyya ādittaṃ tiṇukkaṃ ādāya.
mn21:16.1.eng: Suppose a person was to come along carrying a blazing grass torch,

mn21:16.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ imāya ādittāya tiṇukkāya gaṅgaṃ nadiṃ santāpessāmi samparitāpessāmī’ti.
mn21:16.3.eng: ‘I shall burn and scorch the river Ganges with this blazing grass torch.’

mn21:16.5.pli: api nu so puriso ādittāya tiṇukkāya gaṅgaṃ nadiṃ santāpeyya samparitāpeyyā”ti?
mn21:16.5.eng: Could that person burn and scorch the river Ganges with a blazing grass torch?”

mn21:16.8.eng: Because the river Ganges is deep and limitless.

mn21:16.9.pli: Sā na sukarā ādittāya tiṇukkāya santāpetuṃ samparitāpetuṃ;
mn21:16.9.eng: It’s not easy to burn and scorch it with a blazing grass torch.

mn21:16.10.pli: yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
mn21:16.10.eng: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

mn21:17.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, pañcime vacanapathā yehi vo pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ kālena vā akālena vā …pe…
mn21:17.1.eng: “In the same way, if others criticize you in any of these five ways … you should train like this:

mn21:17.2.pli: tadārammaṇañca sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ gaṅgāsamena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharissāmā’ti.
mn21:17.2.eng: ‘… We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that individual. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart like the Ganges to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’

mn21:18.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, biḷārabhastā madditā sumadditā suparimadditā, mudukā tūlinī chinnasassarā chinnabhabbharā.
mn21:18.1.eng: Suppose there was a catskin bag that was rubbed, well-rubbed, very well-rubbed, soft, silky, rid of rustling and crackling.

mn21:18.2.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya kaṭṭhaṃ vā kathalaṃ vā ādāya.
mn21:18.2.eng: Then a person comes along carrying a stick or a stone,

mn21:18.4.pli: ‘ahaṃ imaṃ biḷārabhastaṃ madditaṃ sumadditaṃ suparimadditaṃ, mudukaṃ tūliniṃ, chinnasassaraṃ chinnabhabbharaṃ kaṭṭhena vā kathalena vā sarasaraṃ karissāmi bharabharaṃ karissāmī’ti.
mn21:18.4.eng: ‘I shall make this soft catskin bag rustle and crackle with this stick or stone.’

mn21:18.6.pli: api nu so puriso amuṃ biḷārabhastaṃ madditaṃ sumadditaṃ suparimadditaṃ, mudukaṃ tūliniṃ, chinnasassaraṃ chinnabhabbharaṃ kaṭṭhena vā kathalena vā sarasaraṃ kareyya, bharabharaṃ kareyyā”ti?
mn21:18.6.eng: Could that person make that soft catskin bag rustle and crackle with that stick or stone?”

mn21:18.9.pli: “Amu hi, bhante, biḷārabhastā madditā sumadditā suparimadditā, mudukā tūlinī, chinnasassarā chinnabhabbharā.
mn21:18.9.eng: Because that catskin bag is rubbed, well-rubbed, very well-rubbed, soft, silky, rid of rustling and crackling.

mn21:18.10.pli: Sā na sukarā kaṭṭhena vā kathalena vā sarasaraṃ kātuṃ bharabharaṃ kātuṃ;
mn21:18.10.eng: It’s not easy to make it rustle or crackle with a stick or stone.

mn21:18.11.pli: yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
mn21:18.11.eng: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

mn21:19.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, pañcime vacanapathā yehi vo pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ
mn21:19.1.eng: “In the same way, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you.

mn21:19.2.eng: Their speech may be timely or untimely,

mn21:19.6.eng: from a heart of love or from secret hate.

mn21:19.7.pli: Kālena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ akālena vā;
mn21:19.7.eng: When others criticize you, they may do so in any of these ways.

mn21:19.8.pli: bhūtena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ abhūtena vā;

mn21:19.9.pli: saṇhena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ pharusena vā;

mn21:19.10.pli: atthasaṃhitena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ anatthasaṃhitena vā;

mn21:19.11.pli: mettacittā vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṃ dosantarā vā.

mn21:19.12.eng: If that happens, you should train like this:

mn21:19.13.pli: ‘na ceva no cittaṃ vipariṇataṃ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṃ vācaṃ nicchāressāma hitānukampī ca viharissāma mettacittā na dosantarā.
mn21:19.13.eng: ‘Our minds will not degenerate. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.

mn21:19.14.pli: Tañca puggalaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā pharitvā viharissāma, tadārammaṇañca sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ biḷārabhastāsamena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharissāmā’ti.
mn21:19.14.eng: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that individual. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart like a catskin bag to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’

mn21:20.1.pli: Ubhatodaṇḍakena cepi, bhikkhave, kakacena corā ocarakā aṅgamaṅgāni okanteyyuṃ, tatrāpi yo mano padūseyya, na me so tena sāsanakaro.
mn21:20.1.eng: Even if low-down bandits were to sever you limb from limb with a two-handed saw, anyone who had a malevolent thought on that account would not be following my instructions.
mn21:20.1.comm: This is often depicted as one of the torments of hell.

mn21:20.2.eng: If that happens, you should train like this:

mn21:20.3.pli: ‘na ceva no cittaṃ vipariṇataṃ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṃ vācaṃ nicchāressāma, hitānukampī ca viharissāma mettacittā na dosantarā.
mn21:20.3.eng: ‘Our minds will not degenerate. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.

mn21:20.4.pli: Tañca puggalaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā pharitvā viharissāma tadārammaṇañca sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharissāmā’ti.
mn21:20.4.eng: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that individual. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart full of love to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’

mn21:21.1.pli: Imañca tumhe, bhikkhave, kakacūpamaṃ ovādaṃ abhikkhaṇaṃ manasi kareyyātha.
mn21:21.1.eng: If you frequently reflect on this advice on the simile of the saw,
mn21:21.1.comm: This dramatic passage is quoted at MN 28:24.3, which adopts the name “The Advice on the Simile of the Saw” (kakacūpamovāda). It became one of the most famous similes in Buddhism. In addition to these two Majjhima suttas and their Chinese parallels, it is cited in canonical texts at Thag 6.12:5.2 and SA 497, and in commentarial texts such as the Sanskrit Abhidharma text Mahāvibhāṣā (T 1545 at T xxvii 190a28), the Pali commentary to Ud 3.3, and the Visuddhimagga chapter on loving-kindness meditation (Vsm 2.9.15). A similar sentiment, moreover, is expressed in the Jain Isibhāsiyāiṁ chapter 34.

mn21:21.2.pli: Passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, taṃ vacanapathaṃ, aṇuṃ vā thūlaṃ vā, yaṃ tumhe nādhivāseyyāthā”ti?
mn21:21.2.eng: do you see any criticism, large or small, that you could not endure?”

mn21:21.4.pli: “Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, imaṃ kakacūpamaṃ ovādaṃ abhikkhaṇaṃ manasikarotha.
mn21:21.4.eng: “So, mendicants, you should frequently reflect on this advice on the simile of the saw.

mn21:21.5.pli: Taṃ vo bhavissati dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
mn21:21.5.eng: This will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.”

mn21:21.6.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn21:21.7.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn21:21.7.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
